scene.scenepersonae: (King of Navarre, Berowne, Longaville, Dumaine, Constable Dull, Costard)
scene.stagedir: Enter Ferdinand, King of Navarre, Berowne, Longaville, and Dumaine.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Let fame, that all hunt after in their lives,
Live regist’red upon our brazen tombs,
And then grace us in the disgrace of death;
When spite of cormorant devouring Time,
Th’ endeavor of this present breath may buy
That honor which shall bate his scythe’s keen edge,
And make us heirs of all eternity.
Therefore, brave conquerors—for so you are,
That war against your own affections
And the huge army of the world’s desires—
Our late edict shall strongly stand in force:
Navarre shall be the wonder of the world;
Our court shall be a little academe,
Still and contemplative in living art.
You three, Berowne, Dumaine, and Longaville,
Have sworn for three years’ term to live with me,
My fellow scholars, and to keep those statutes
That are recorded in this schedule here.
Your oaths are pass’d, and now subscribe your names,
That his own hand may strike his honor down
That violates the smallest branch herein.
If you are arm’d to do, as sworn to do,
Subscribe to your deep oaths, and keep it too.

speech.speaker: LONG.
speech.line: I am resolved, ’tis but a three years’ fast:
The mind shall banquet, though the body pine;
Fat paunches have lean pates; and dainty bits
Make rich the ribs, but bankrout quite the wits.

speech.speaker: DUM.
speech.line: My loving lord, Dumaine is mortified:
The grosser manner of these world’s delights
He throws upon the gross world’s baser slaves;
To love, to wealth, to pomp, I pine and die,
With all these living in philosophy.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: I can but say their protestation over:
So much, dear liege, I have already sworn,
That is, to live and study here three years.
But there are other strict observances:
As not to see a woman in that term,
Which I hope well is not enrolled there;
And one day in a week to touch no food,
And but one meal on every day beside,
The which I hope is not enrolled there;
And then to sleep but three hours in the night,
And not be seen to wink of all the day—
When I was wont to think no harm all night,
And make a dark night too of half the day—
Which I hope well is not enrolled there.
O, these are barren tasks, too hard to keep,
Not to see ladies, study, fast, not sleep.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Your oath is pass’d to pass away from these.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Let me say no, my liege, and if you please:
I only swore to study with your Grace,
And stay here in your court for three years’ space.

speech.speaker: LONG.
speech.line: You swore to that, Berowne, and to the rest.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: By yea and nay, sir, then I swore in jest.
What is the end of study, let me know.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Why, that to know which else we should not know.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Things hid and barr’d (you mean) from common sense.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Ay, that is study’s godlike recompense.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Com’ on then, I will swear to study so,
To know the thing I am forbid to know:
As thus—to study where I well may dine,
When I to feast expressly am forbid;
Or study where to meet some mistress fine,
When mistresses from common sense are hid;
Or having sworn too hard-a-keeping oath,
Study to break it and not break my troth.
If study’s gain be thus, and this be so,
Study knows that which yet it doth not know.
Swear me to this, and I will ne’er say no.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: These be the stops that hinder study quite,
And train our intellects to vain delight.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Why? All delights are vain, but that most vain
Which, with pain purchas’d, doth inherit pain:
As, painfully to pore upon a book
To seek the light of truth, while truth the while
Doth falsely blind the eyesight of his look.
Light, seeking light, doth light of light beguile;
So ere you find where light in darkness lies,
Your light grows dark by losing of your eyes.
Study me how to please the eye indeed
By fixing it upon a fairer eye,
Who dazzling so, that eye shall be his heed,
And give him light that it was blinded by.
Study is like the heaven’s glorious sun,
That will not be deep search’d with saucy looks;
Small have continual plodders ever won,
Save base authority from others’ books.
These earthly godfathers of heaven’s lights,
That give a name to every fixed star,
Have no more profit of their shining nights
Than those that walk and wot not what they are.
Too much to know is to know nought but fame;
And every godfather can give a name.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: How well he’s read, to reason against reading!

speech.speaker: DUM.
speech.line: Proceeded well, to stop all good proceeding!

speech.speaker: LONG.
speech.line: He weeds the corn and still lets grow the weeding.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: The spring is near when green geese are a-breeding.

speech.speaker: DUM.
speech.line: How follows that?

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Fit in his place and time.

speech.speaker: DUM.
speech.line: In reason nothing.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Something then in rhyme.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Berowne is like an envious sneaping frost
That bites the first-born infants of the spring.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Well, say I am, why should proud summer boast
Before the birds have any cause to sing?
Why should I joy in any abortive birth?
At Christmas I no more desire a rose
Than wish a snow in May’s new-fangled shows;
But like of each thing that in season grows.
So you, to study now it is too late,
Climb o’er the house to unlock the little gate.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Well, sit you out; go home, Berowne; adieu.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: No, my good lord, I have sworn to stay with you;
And though I have for barbarism spoke more
Than for that angel knowledge you can say,
Yet, confident, I’ll keep what I have sworn,
And bide the penance of each three years’ day.
Give me the paper, let me read the same,
And to the strictest decrees I’ll write my name.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: How well this yielding rescues thee from shame!

line.recite: “Item, That no woman shall come within a mile of my court”—Hath this been proclaim’d?

speech.speaker: LONG.
speech.line: Four days ago.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Let’s see the penalty.

line.recite: “—on pain of losing her tongue.” Who devis’d this penalty?

speech.speaker: LONG.
speech.line: Marry, that did I.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Sweet lord, and why?

speech.speaker: LONG.
speech.line: To fright them hence with that dread penalty.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: A dangerous law against gentility.

line.recite: “Item, If any man be seen to talk with a woman within the term of three years, he shall endure such public shame as the rest of the court can possible devise.”

speech.line: This article, my liege, yourself must break,
For well you know here comes in embassy
The French king’s daughter with yourself to speak—
A maid of grace and complete majesty—
About surrender up of Aquitaine
To her decrepit, sick, and bedred father;
Therefore this article is made in vain,
Or vainly comes th’ admired Princess hither.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: What say you, lords? Why, this was quite forgot.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: So study evermore is overshot:
While it doth study to have what it would,
It doth forget to do the thing it should;
And when it hath the thing it hunteth most,
’Tis won as towns with fire—so won, so lost.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: We must of force dispense with this decree,
She must lie here on mere necessity.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Necessity will make us all forsworn
Three thousand times within this three years’ space;
For every man with his affects is born,
Not by might mast’red, but by special grace.
If I break faith, this word shall speak for me:
I am forsworn “on mere necessity.”
So to the laws at large I write my name,
And he that breaks them in the least degree
Stands in attainder of eternal shame.
Suggestions are to other as to me;
But I believe, although I seem so loath,
I am the last that will last keep his oath.
But is there no quick recreation granted?

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Ay, that there is. Our court you know is haunted
With a refined traveller of Spain,
A man in all the world’s new fashion planted,
That hath a mint of phrases in his brain;
One who the music of his own vain tongue
Doth ravish like enchanting harmony;
A man of complements, whom right and wrong
Have chose as umpeer of their mutiny.
This child of fancy, that Armado hight,
For interim to our studies shall relate,
In high-borne words, the worth of many a knight
From tawny Spain, lost in the world’s debate.
How you delight, my lords, I know not, I,
But I protest I love to hear him lie,
And I will use him for my minstrelsy.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Armado is a most illustrious wight,
A man of fire-new words, fashion’s own knight.

speech.speaker: LONG.
speech.line: Costard the swain and he shall be our sport,
And so to study three years is but short.

scene.stagedir: Enter a Constable Dull with a letter, with Costard.

speech.speaker: DULL.
speech.line: Which is the Duke’s own person?

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: This, fellow. What wouldst?

speech.speaker: DULL.
speech.line: I myself reprehend his own person, for I am his Grace’s farborough; but I would see his own person in flesh and blood.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: This is he.

speech.speaker: DULL.
speech.line: Signior Arme—Arme—commends you. There’s villainy abroad; this letter will tell you more.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: Sir, the contempts thereof are as touching me.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: A letter from the magnificent Armado.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: How low soever the matter, I hope in God for high words.

speech.speaker: LONG.
speech.line: A high hope for a low heaven. God grant us patience!

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: To hear, or forbear hearing?

speech.speaker: LONG.
speech.line: To hear meekly, sir, and to laugh moderately; or to forbear both.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Well, sir, be it as the style shall give us cause to climb in the merriness.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: The matter is to me, sir, as concerning Jaquenetta: the manner of it is, I was taken with the manner.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: In what manner?

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: In manner and form following, sir, all those three: I was seen with her in the manor-house, sitting with her upon the form, and taken following her into the park, which, put together, is in manner and form following. Now, sir, for the manner—it is the manner of a man to speak to a woman; for the form—in some form.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: For the following, sir?

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: As it shall follow in my correction, and God defend the right!

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Will you hear this letter with attention?

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: As we would hear an oracle.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: Such is the simplicity of man to hearken after the flesh.

line.recite: “Great deputy, the welkin’s vicegerent, and sole dominator of Navarre, my soul’s earth’s god, and body’s fost’ring patron”—

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: Not a word of Costard yet.

line.recite: “So it is”—

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: It may be so; but if he say it is so, he is, in telling true—but so.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Peace!

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: —be to me, and every man that dares not fight!

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: No words!

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: —of other men’s secrets, I beseech you.

line.recite: “So it is, besieged with sable-colored melancholy, I did commend the black oppressing humor to the most wholesome physic of thy health-giving air; and as I am a gentleman, betook myself to walk: the time When? About the sixt hour, when beasts most graze, birds best peck, and men sit down to that nourishment which is called supper: so much for the time When. Now for the ground Which? Which, I mean, I walk’d upon: it is ycliped thy park. Then for the place Where? Where, I mean, I did encounter that obscene and most prepost’rous event that draweth from my snow-white pen the ebon-colored ink which here thou viewest, beholdest, surveyest, or seest. But to the place Where? It standeth north-north-east and by east from the west corner of thy curious-knotted garden. There did I see that low-spirited swain, that base minnow of thy mirth”—

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: Me?

line.recite: “that unlettered small-knowing soul”—

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: Me?

line.recite: “that shallow vassal”—

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: Still me?

line.recite: “which, as I remember, hight Costard”—

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: O! Me.

line.recite: “sorted and consorted, contrary to thy established proclaimed edict and continent canon; which with—O, with—but with this I passion to say wherewith”—

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: With a wench.

line.recite: “with a child of our grandmother Eve, a female; or for thy more sweet understanding, a woman. Him I (as my ever-esteemed duty pricks me on) have sent to thee, to receive the meed of punishment, by thy sweet Grace’s officer, Anthony Dull, a man of good repute, carriage, bearing, and estimation.”

speech.speaker: DULL.
speech.line: Me, an’t shall please you: I am Anthony Dull.

line.recite: “For Jaquenetta (so is the weaker vessel called), which I apprehended with the aforesaid swain, I keep her as a vessel of thy law’s fury, and shall, at the least of thy sweet notice, bring her to trial. Thine, in all complements of devoted and heart-burning heat of duty,
Don Adriano de Armado.”

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: This is not so well as I look’d for, but the best that ever I heard.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Ay, the best for the worst. But, sirrah, what say you to this?

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: Sir, I confess the wench.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Did you hear the proclamation?

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: I do confess much of the hearing it, but little of the marking of it.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: It was proclaim’d a year’s imprisonment to be taken with a wench.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: I was taken with none, sir, I was taken with a damsel.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Well, it was proclaim’d damsel.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: This was no damsel neither, sir, she was a virgin.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: It is so varied too, for it was proclaim’d virgin.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: If it were, I deny her virginity; I was taken with a maid.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: This maid will not serve your turn, sir.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: This maid will serve my turn, sir.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Sir, I will pronounce your sentence: you shall fast a week with bran and water.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: I had rather pray a month with mutton and porridge.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: And Don Armado shall be your keeper.
My Lord Berowne, see him delivered o’er,
And go we, lords, to put in practice that
Which each to other hath so strongly sworn.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: I’ll lay my head to any good man’s hat,
These oaths and laws will prove an idle scorn.
Sirrah, come on.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: I suffer for the truth, sir; for true it is, I was taken with Jaquenetta, and Jaquenetta is a true girl, and therefore welcome the sour cup of prosperity! Affliction may one day smile again, and till then, sit thee down, sorrow!

scene.scenepersonae: (Armado, Moth, Clown Costard, Constable Dull, Wench Jaquenetta)
scene.stagedir: Enter Armado and Moth, his page.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Boy, what sign is it when a man of great spirit grows melancholy?

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: A great sign, sir, that he will look sad.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Why, sadness is one and the self-same thing, dear imp.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: No, no, O Lord, sir, no.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: How canst thou part sadness and melancholy, my tender juvenal?

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: By a familiar demonstration of the working, my tough signior.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Why tough signior? Why tough signior?

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: Why tender juvenal? Why tender juvenal?

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: I spoke it tender juvenal as a congruent epitheton appertaining to thy young days, which we may nominate tender.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: And I tough signior as an appertinent title to your old time, which we may name tough.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Pretty and apt.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: How mean you, sir? I pretty, and my saying apt? Or I apt, and my saying pretty?

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Thou pretty, because little.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: Little pretty, because little. Wherefore apt?

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: And therefore apt, because quick.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: Speak you this in my praise, master?

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: In thy condign praise.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: I will praise an eel with the same praise.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: What? That an eel is ingenious?

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: That an eel is quick.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: I do say thou art quick in answers; thou heat’st my blood.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: I am answer’d, sir.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: I love not to be cross’d.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: He speaks the mere contrary, crosses love not him.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: I have promised to study three years with the Duke.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: You may do it in an hour, sir.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Impossible.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: How many is one thrice told?

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: I am ill at reck’ning, it fitteth the spirit of a tapster.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: You are a gentleman and a gamester, sir.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: I confess both, they are both the varnish of a complete man.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: Then I am sure you know how much the gross sum of deuce-ace amounts to.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: It doth amount to one more than two.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: Which the base vulgar do call three.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: True.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: Why, sir, is this such a piece of study? Now here is three studied ere ye’ll thrice wink; and how easy it is to put “years” to the word “three,” and study three years in two words, the dancing horse will tell you.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: A most fine figure!

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: To prove you a cipher.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: I will hereupon confess I am in love; and as it is base for a soldier to love, so am I in love with a base wench. If drawing my sword against the humor of affection would deliver me from the reprobate thought of it, I would take Desire prisoner, and ransom him to any French courtier for a new devis’d cur’sy. I think scorn to sigh; methinks I should outswear Cupid. Comfort me, boy: what great men have been in love?

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: Hercules, master.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Most sweet Hercules! More authority, dear boy, name more; and, sweet my child, let them be men of good repute and carriage.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: Sampson, master; he was a man of good carriage, great carriage, for he carried the town gates on his back like a porter; and he was in love.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: O well-knit Sampson, strong-jointed Sampson! I do excel thee in my rapier as much as thou didst me in carrying gates. I am in love too. Who was Sampson’s love, my dear Moth?

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: A woman, master.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Of what complexion?

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: Of all the four, or the three, or the two, or one of the four.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Tell me precisely of what complexion.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: Of the sea-water green, sir.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Is that one of the four complexions?

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: As I have read, sir, and the best of them too.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Green indeed is the color of lovers; but to have a love of that color, methinks Sampson had small reason for it. He surely affected her for her wit.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: It was so, sir, for she had a green wit.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: My love is most immaculate white and red.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: Most maculate thoughts, master, are mask’d under such colors.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Define, define, well-educated infant.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: My father’s wit and my mother’s tongue assist me!

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Sweet invocation of a child, most pretty and pathetical!

speech.speaker: MOTH.

line.recite: If she be made of white and red,
Her faults will ne’er be known,
For blush in cheeks by faults are bred,
And fears by pale white shown:
Then if she fear, or be to blame,
By this you shall not know,
For still her cheeks possess the same
Which native she doth owe.

speech.line: A dangerous rhyme, master, against the reason of white and red.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Is there not a ballet, boy, of the King and the Beggar?

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: The world was very guilty of such a ballet some three ages since, but I think now ’tis not to be found; or if it were, it would neither serve for the writing nor the tune.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: I will have that subject newly writ o’er, that I may example my digression by some mighty president. Boy, I do love that country girl that I took in the park with the rational hind Costard. She deserves well.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: To be whipt; and yet a better love than my master.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Sing, boy, my spirit grows heavy in love.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: And that’s great marvel, loving a light wench.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: I say, sing.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: Forbear till this company be past.

scene.stagedir: Enter Clown Costard, Constable Dull, and Wench Jaquenetta.

speech.speaker: DULL.
speech.line: Sir, the Duke’s pleasure is that you keep Costard safe, and you must suffer him to take no delight nor no penance, but ’a must fast three days a week. For this damsel, I must keep her at the park; she is allow’d for the dey-woman. Fare you well.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: I do betray myself with blushing. Maid.

speech.speaker: JAQ.
speech.line: Man.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: I will visit thee at the lodge.

speech.speaker: JAQ.
speech.line: That’s hereby.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: I know where it is situate.

speech.speaker: JAQ.
speech.line: Lord, how wise you are!

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: I will tell thee wonders.

speech.speaker: JAQ.
speech.line: With that face?

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: I love thee.

speech.speaker: JAQ.
speech.line: So I heard you say.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: And so farewell.

speech.speaker: JAQ.
speech.line: Fair weather after you!

speech.speaker: DULL.
speech.line: Come, Jaquenetta, away.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Villain, thou shalt fast for thy offenses ere thou be pardoned.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: Well, sir, I hope when I do it I shall do it on a full stomach.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Thou shalt be heavily punished.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: I am more bound to you than your fellows, for they are but lightly rewarded.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Take away this villain, shut him up.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: Come, you transgressing slave, away.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: Let me not be pent up, sir; I will fast, being loose.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: No, sir, that were fast and loose; thou shalt to prison.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: Well, if ever I do see the merry days of desolation that I have seen, some shall see.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: What shall some see?

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: Nay, nothing, Master Moth, but what they look upon. It is not for prisoners to be too silent in their words, and therefore I will say nothing. I thank God I have as little patience as another man, and therefore I can be quiet.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: I do affect the very ground (which is base) where her shoe (which is baser) guided by her foot (which is basest) doth tread. I shall be forsworn (which is a great argument of falsehood) if I love. And how can that be true love, which is falsely attempted? Love is a familiar; Love is a devil; there is no evil angel but Love. Yet was Sampson so tempted, and he had an excellent strength; yet was Salomon so seduced, and he had a very good wit. Cupid’s butt-shaft is too hard for Hercules’ club, and therefore too much odds for a Spaniard’s rapier. The first and second cause will not serve my turn; the passado he respects not, the duello he regards not: his disgrace is to be called boy, but his glory is to subdue men. Adieu, valor, rust, rapier, be still, drum, for your manager is in love; yea, he loveth. Assist me, some extemporal god of rhyme, for I am sure I shall turn sonnet. Devise, wit, write, pen, for I am for whole volumes in folio.

scene.scenepersonae: (Princess of France, Rosaline, Maria, Katherine, First French Lord, Lords, Boyet, King of Navarre, Longaville, Dumaine, Berowne, Attendants)
scene.stagedir: Enter the Princess of France with three attending Ladies (Rosaline, Maria, Katherine) and three Lords, one named Boyet.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: Now, madam, summon up your dearest spirits;
Consider who the King your father sends,
To whom he sends, and what’s his embassy:
Yourself, held precious in the world’s esteem,
To parley with the sole inheritor
Of all perfections that a man may owe,
Matchless Navarre; the plea of no less weight
Than Aquitaine, a dowry for a queen.
Be now as prodigal of all dear grace
As Nature was in making graces dear,
When she did starve the general world beside
And prodigally gave them all to you.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Good Lord Boyet, my beauty, though but mean,
Needs not the painted flourish of your praise:
Beauty is bought by judgment of the eye,
Not utt’red by base sale of chapmen’s tongues.
I am less proud to hear you tell my worth
Than you much willing to be counted wise
In spending your wit in the praise of mine.
But now to task the tasker: good Boyet,
You are not ignorant all-telling fame
Doth noise abroad Navarre hath made a vow,
Till painful study shall outwear three years,
No woman may approach his silent court;
Therefore to ’s seemeth it a needful course,
Before we enter his forbidden gates,
To know his pleasure; and in that behalf,
Bold of your worthiness, we single you
As our best-moving fair solicitor.
Tell him, the daughter of the King of France,
On serious business craving quick dispatch,
Importunes personal conference with his Grace.
Haste, signify so much, while we attend,
Like humble-visag’d suitors, his high will.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: Proud of employment, willingly I go.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: All pride is willing pride, and yours is so.
Who are the votaries, my loving lords,
That are vow-fellows with this virtuous Duke?

speech.speaker: 1. FR. LORD.
speech.line: Lord Longaville is one.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Know you the man?

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: I know him, madam; at a marriage-feast,
Between Lord Perigort and the beauteous heir
Of Jaques Falconbridge, solemnized
In Normandy, saw I this Longaville,
A man of sovereign parts, peerless esteem’d,
Well fitted in arts, glorious in arms;
Nothing becomes him ill that he would well.
The only soil of his fair virtue’s gloss,
If virtue’s gloss will stain with any soil,
Is a sharp wit match’d with too blunt a will,
Whose edge hath power to cut, whose will still wills
It should none spare that come within his power.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Some merry mocking lord belike, is’t so?

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: They say so most that most his humors know.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Such short-liv’d wits do wither as they grow.
Who are the rest?

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: The young Dumaine, a well-accomplish’d youth,
Of all that virtue love for virtue loved;
Most power to do most harm, least knowing ill;
For he hath wit to make an ill shape good,
And shape to win grace though he had no wit.
I saw him at the Duke Alanson’s once,
And much too little of that good I saw
Is my report to his great worthiness.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Another of these students at that time
Was there with him, if I have heard a truth.
Berowne they call him, but a merrier man,
Within the limit of becoming mirth,
I never spent an hour’s talk withal.
His eye begets occasion for his wit,
For every object that the one doth catch
The other turns to a mirth-moving jest,
Which his fair tongue, conceit’s expositor,
Delivers in such apt and gracious words
That aged ears play truant at his tales,
And younger hearings are quite ravished,
So sweet and voluble is his discourse.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: God bless my ladies! Are they all in love,
That every one her own hath garnished
With such bedecking ornaments of praise?

speech.speaker: 1. FR. LORD.
speech.line: Here comes Boyet.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Now, what admittance, lord?

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: Navarre had notice of your fair approach,
And he and his competitors in oath
Were all address’d to meet you, gentle lady,
Before I came. Marry, thus much I have learnt:
He rather means to lodge you in the field,
Like one that comes here to besiege his court,
Than seek a dispensation for his oath,
To let you enter his unpeopled house.
speech.stagedir: Enter Ferdinand, King of Navarre, Longaville, Dumaine, and Berowne, and Attendants.
speech.line: Here comes Navarre.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Fair Princess, welcome to the court of Navarre.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: “Fair” I give you back again, and “welcome” I have not yet. The roof of this court is too high to be yours, and welcome to the wide fields too base to be mine.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: You shall be welcome, madam, to my court.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: I will be welcome then—conduct me thither.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Hear me, dear lady: I have sworn an oath.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Our Lady help my lord! He’ll be forsworn.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Not for the world, fair madam, by my will.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Why, will shall break it, will, and nothing else.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Your ladyship is ignorant what it is.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Were my lord so, his ignorance were wise,
Where now his knowledge must prove ignorance.
I hear your Grace hath sworn out house-keeping:
’Tis deadly sin to keep that oath, my lord,
And sin to break it.
But pardon me, I am too sudden bold;
To teach a teacher ill beseemeth me.
Vouchsafe to read the purpose of my coming,
And suddenly resolve me in my suit.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Madam, I will, if suddenly I may.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: You will the sooner, that I were away,
For You’ll prove perjur’d if you make me stay.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Did not I dance with you in Brabant once?

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Did not I dance with you in Brabant once?

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: I know you did.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: How needless was it then
To ask the question?

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: You must not be so quick.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: ’Tis long of you that spur me with such questions.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Your wit’s too hot, it speeds too fast, ’twill tire.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Not till it leave the rider in the mire.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: What time a’ day?

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: The hour that fools should ask.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Now fair befall your mask!

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Fair fall the face it covers!

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: And send you many lovers!

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Amen, so you be none.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Nay then will I be gone.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Madam, your father here doth intimate
The payment of a hundred thousand crowns,
Being but the one half of an entire sum
Disbursed by my father in his wars.
But say that he, or we, as neither have,
Receiv’d that sum, yet there remains unpaid
A hundred thousand more, in surety of the which
One part of Aquitaine is bound to us,
Although not valued to the money’s worth.
If then the King your father will restore
But that one half which is unsatisfied,
We will give up our right in Aquitaine,
And hold fair friendship with his Majesty.
But that, it seems, he little purposeth:
For here he doth demand to have repaid
A hundred thousand crowns, and not demands,
On payment of a hundred thousand crowns,
To have his title live in Aquitaine;
Which we much rather had depart withal,
And have the money by our father lent,
Than Aquitaine, so gelded as it is.
Dear Princess, were not his requests so far
From reason’s yielding, your fair self should make
A yielding ’gainst some reason in my breast,
And go well satisfied to France again.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: You do the King my father too much wrong,
And wrong the reputation of your name,
In so unseeming to confess receipt
Of that which hath so faithfully been paid.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: I do protest I never heard of it;
And, if you prove it, I’ll repay it back,
Or yield up Aquitaine.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: We arrest your word.
Boyet, you can produce acquittances
For such a sum from special officers
Of Charles his father.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Satisfy me so.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: So please your Grace, the packet is not come
Where that and other specialties are bound:
Tomorrow you shall have a sight of them.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: It shall suffice me; at which interview
All liberal reason I will yield unto.
Mean time receive such welcome at my hand
As honor (without breach of honor) may
Make tender of to thy true worthiness.
You may not come, fair Princess, within my gates,
But here without you shall be so receiv’d
As you shall deem yourself lodg’d in my heart,
Though so denied fair harbor in my house.
Your own good thoughts excuse me, and farewell.
Tomorrow shall we visit you again.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Sweet health and fair desires consort your Grace!

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Thy own wish wish I thee in every place.

scene.stagedir: Exit with Longaville, Dumaine, and Attendants.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: Lady, I will commend you to mine own heart.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Pray you, do my commendations—I would be glad to see it.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: I would you heard it groan.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Is the fool sick?

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: Sick at the heart.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Alack, let it blood.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: Would that do it good?

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: My physic says ay.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: Will you prick’t with your eye?

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: No point, with my knife.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: Now God save thy life!

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: And yours from long living!

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: I cannot stay thanksgiving.

speech.speaker: DUM.
speech.line: Sir, I pray you a word. What lady is that same?

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: The heir of Alanson, Katherine her name.

speech.speaker: DUM.
speech.line: A gallant lady. Monsieur, fare you well.

speech.speaker: LONG.
speech.line: I beseech you a word. What is she in the white?

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: A woman sometimes, and you saw her in the light.

speech.speaker: LONG.
speech.line: Perchance light in the light. I desire her name.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: She hath but one for herself, to desire that were a shame.

speech.speaker: LONG.
speech.line: Pray you, sir, whose daughter?

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: Her mother’s, I have heard.

speech.speaker: LONG.
speech.line: God’s blessing on your beard!

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: Good sir, be not offended,
She is an heir of Falconbridge.

speech.speaker: LONG.
speech.line: Nay, my choler is ended.
She is a most sweet lady.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: Not unlike, sir, that may be.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: What’s her name in the cap?

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: Rosaline, by good hap.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Is she wedded or no?

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: To her will, sir, or so.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: O, you are welcome, sir, adieu.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: Farewell to me, sir, and welcome to you.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: That last is Berowne, the merry madcap lord.
Not a word with him but a jest.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: And every jest but a word.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: It was well done of you to take him at his word.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: I was as willing to grapple as he was to board.

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: Two hot sheeps, marry.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: And wherefore not ships?
No sheep, sweet lamb, unless we feed on your lips.

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: You sheep, and I pasture: shall that finish the jest?

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: So you grant pasture for me.

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: Not so, gentle beast.
My lips are no common, though several they be.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: Belonging to whom?

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: To my fortunes and me.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Good wits will be jangling, but, gentles, agree:
This civil war of wits were much better used
On Navarre and his book-men, for here ’tis abused.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: If my observation (which very seldom lies),
By the heart’s still rhetoric, disclosed with eyes,
Deceive me not now, Navarre is infected.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: With what?

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: With that which we lovers entitle “affected.”

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Your reason?

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: Why, all his behaviors did make their retire
To the court of his eye, peeping thorough desire:
His heart like an agot with your print impressed,
Proud with his form, in his eye pride expressed;
His tongue, all impatient to speak and not see,
Did stumble with haste in his eyesight to be;
All senses to that sense did make their repair,
To feel only looking on fairest of fair:
Methought all his senses were lock’d in his eye,
As jewels in crystal for some prince to buy,
Who tend’ring their own worth from where they were glass’d,
Did point you to buy them, along as you pass’d;
His face’s own margent did quote such amazes
That all eyes saw his eyes enchanted with gazes.
I’ll give you Aquitaine and all that is his,
And you give him for my sake but one loving kiss.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Come to our pavilion—Boyet is dispos’d.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: But to speak that in words which his eye hath disclos’d.
I only have made a mouth of his eye,
By adding a tongue which I know will not lie.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Thou art an old love-monger and speakest skillfully.

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: He is Cupid’s grandfather, and learns news of him.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Then was Venus like her mother, for her father is but grim.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: Do you hear, my mad wenches?

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: No.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: What then, do you see?

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Ay, our way to be gone.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: You are too hard for me.

scene.stagedir: Enter Braggart Armado and his Boy Moth.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Warble, child, make passionate my sense of hearing.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: “Concolinel.”

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Sweet air! Go, tenderness of years, take this key, give enlargement to the swain, bring him festinately hither. I must employ him in a letter to my love.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: Master, will you win your love with a French brawl?

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: How meanest thou? Brawling in French?

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: No, my complete master, but to jig off a tune at the tongue’s end, canary to it with your feet, humor it with turning up your eyelids, sigh a note and sing a note, sometime through the throat, as if you swallow’d love with singing love, sometime through the nose, as if you snuff’d up love by smelling love; with your hat penthouse-like o’er the shop of your eyes; with your arms cross’d on your thin-bellied doublet like a rabbit on a spit; or your hands in your pocket like a man after the old painting; and keep not too long in one tune, but a snip and away: these are complements, these are humors, these betray nice wenches that would be betray’d without these; and make them men of note—do you note?—men that most are affected to these.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: How hast thou purchased this experience?

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: By my penny of observation.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: But O—but O—

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: “The hobby-horse is forgot.”

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Call’st thou my love “hobby-horse”?

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: No, master, the hobby-horse is but a colt, Aside and your love perhaps a hackney.—But have you forgot your love?

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Almost I had.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: Negligent student, learn her by heart.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: By heart and in heart, boy.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: And out of heart, master; all those three I will prove.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: What wilt thou prove?

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: A man, if I live; and this, “by, in, and without,” upon the instant: by heart you love her, because your heart cannot come by her; in heart you love her, because your heart is in love with her; and out of heart you love her, being out of heart that you cannot enjoy her.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: I am all these three.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: And three times as much more—
and yet nothing at all.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Fetch hither the swain, he must carry me a letter.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: A message well sympathiz’d—a horse to be embassador for an ass.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Ha, ha? What sayest thou?

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: Marry, sir, you must send the ass upon the horse, for he is very slow-gaited. But I go.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: The way is but short, away!

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: As swift as lead, sir.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: The meaning, pretty ingenious?
Is not lead a metal heavy, dull, and slow?

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: Minime, honest master, or rather, master, no.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: I say lead is slow.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: You are too swift, sir, to say so.
Is that lead slow which is fir’d from a gun?

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Sweet smoke of rhetoric!
He reputes me a cannon, and the bullet, that’s he;
I shoot thee at the swain.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: Thump then, and I flee.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: A most acute juvenal, volable and free of grace!
By thy favor, sweet welkin, I must sigh in thy face:
Most rude melancholy, valor gives thee place.
My herald is return’d.

scene.stagedir: Enter Page Moth and Clown Costard.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: A wonder, master! Here’s a costard broken in a shin.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Some enigma, some riddle—come, thy l’envoy—begin.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: No egma, no riddle, no l’envoy, no salve in the mail, sir. O sir, plantan, a plain plantan; no l’envoy, no l’envoy, no salve, sir, but a plantan!

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: By virtue thou enforcest laughter—thy silly thought, my spleen; the heaving of my lungs provokes me to ridiculous smiling—O, pardon me, my stars! Doth the inconsiderate take salve for l’envoy, and the word “l’envoy” for a salve?

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: Do the wise think them other? Is not l’envoy a salve?

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: No, page, it is an epilogue or discourse, to make plain
Some obscure precedence that hath tofore been sain.
I will example it:

line.recite: The fox, the ape, and the humble-bee
Were still at odds, being but three.

speech.line: There’s the moral. Now the l’envoy.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: I will add the l’envoy. Say the moral again.

line.recite: The fox, the ape, and the humble-bee
Were still at odds, being but three.

speech.speaker: MOTH.

line.recite: Until the goose came out of door,
And stayed the odds by adding four.

speech.line: Now will I begin your moral, and do you follow with my l’envoy:

line.recite: The fox, the ape, and the humble-bee
Were still at odds, being but three.
Until the goose came out of door,
Staying the odds by adding four.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: A good l’envoy, ending in the goose; would you desire more?

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: The boy hath sold him a bargain, a goose, that’s flat.
Sir, your pennyworth is good, and your goose be fat.
To sell a bargain well is as cunning as fast and loose:
Let me see: a fat l’envoy—ay, that’s a fat goose.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Come hither, come hither. How did this argument begin?

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: By saying that a costard was broken in a shin.
Then call’d you for the l’envoy.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: True, and I for a plantan; thus came your argument in;
Then the boy’s fat l’envoy, the goose that you bought,
And he ended the market.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: But tell me, how was there a costard broken in a shin?

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: I will tell you sensibly.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: Thou hast no feeling of it, Moth. I will speak that l’envoy:
I, Costard, running out that was safely within,
Fell over the threshold, and broke my shin.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: We will talk no more of this matter.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: Till there be more matter in the shin.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Sirrah Costard, I will enfranchise thee.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: O, marry me to one Frances! I smell some l’envoy, some goose, in this.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: By my sweet soul, I mean setting thee at liberty, enfreedoming thy person: thou wert immured, restrained, captivated, bound.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: True, true, and now you will be my purgation and let me loose.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: I give thee thy liberty, set thee from durance, and in lieu thereof, impose on thee nothing but this: bear this significant
to the country maid Jaquenetta. There is remuneration, for the best ward of mine honor is rewarding my dependants. Moth, follow.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: Like the sequel, I. Signior Costard, adieu.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: My sweet ounce of man’s flesh, my incony Jew!

Now will I look to his remuneration. Remuneration! O, that’s the Latin word for three farthings: three farthings—remuneration. “What’s the price of this inkle?”—“One penny.”—“No, I’ll give you a remuneration” : why, it carries it. Remuneration: why, it is a fairer name than French crown! I will never buy and sell out of this word.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: O, my good knave Costard, exceedingly well met!

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: Pray you, sir, how much carnation ribbon may a man buy for a remuneration?

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: O, what is a remuneration?

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: Marry, sir, halfpenny farthing.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: O, why then three-farthing worth of silk.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: I thank your worship, God be wi’ you!

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: O, stay, slave; I must employ thee.
As thou wilt win my favor, good my knave,
Do one thing for me that I shall entreat.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: When would you have it done, sir?

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: O, this afternoon.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: Well, I will do it, sir; fare you well.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: O, thou knowest not what it is.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: I shall know, sir, when I have done it.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Why, villain, thou must know first.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: I will come to your worship tomorrow morning.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: It must be done this afternoon. Hark, slave, it is but this:
The Princess comes to hunt here in the park,
And in her train there is a gentle lady:
When tongues speak sweetly, then they name her name,
And Rosaline they call her. Ask for her,
And to her white hand see thou do commend
This seal’d-up counsel. There’s thy guerdon; go.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: Garden, O sweet gardon! Better than remuneration, aleven-pence-farthing better; most sweet gardon! I will do it, sir, in print. Gardon! Remuneration!

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: O, and I, forsooth, in love! I, that have been love’s whip,
A very beadle to a humorous sigh,
A critic, nay, a night-watch constable,
A domineering pedant o’er the boy,
Than whom no mortal so magnificent!
This wimpled, whining, purblind, wayward boy,
This senior-junior, giant-dwarf, Dan Cupid,
Regent of love-rhymes, lord of folded arms,
Th’ anointed sovereign of sighs and groans,
Liege of all loiterers and malecontents,
Dread prince of plackets, king of codpieces,
Sole imperator and great general
Of trotting paritors (O my little heart!),
And I to be a corporal of his field,
And wear his colors like a tumbler’s hoop!
What! I love, I sue, I seek a wife—
A woman, that is like a German clock,
Still a-repairing, ever out of frame,
And never going aright, being a watch,
But being watch’d that it may still go right!
Nay, to be perjur’d, which is worst of all;
And among three to love the worst of all,
A whitely wanton with a velvet brow,
With two pitch-balls stuck in her face for eyes;
Ay, and, by heaven, one that will do the deed
Though Argus were her eunuch and her guard.
And I to sigh for her, to watch for her,
To pray for her, go to! It is a plague
That Cupid will impose for my neglect
Of his almighty dreadful little might.
Well, I will love, write, sigh, pray, sue, groan:
Some men must love my lady, and some Joan.

scene.scenepersonae: (Princess, Forester, Rosaline, Maria, Katherine, Lords, Boyet, Costard)
scene.stagedir: Enter the Princess, a Forester, her Ladies (Rosaline, Maria, Katherine), and her Lords, among them Boyet.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Was that the King that spurr’d his horse so hard
Against the steep-up rising of the hill?

speech.speaker: FOR.
speech.line: I know not, but I think it was not he.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Whoe’er ’a was, ’a show’d a mounting mind.
Well, lords, today we shall have our dispatch;
On Saturday we will return to France.
Then, forester, my friend, where is the bush
That we must stand and play the murderer in?

speech.speaker: FOR.
speech.line: Hereby, upon the edge of yonder coppice,
A stand where you may make the fairest shoot.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: I thank my beauty, I am fair that shoot,
And thereupon thou speak’st the fairest shoot.

speech.speaker: FOR.
speech.line: Pardon me, madam, for I meant not so.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: What, what? First praise me, and again say no?
O short-liv’d pride! Not fair? Alack for woe!

speech.speaker: FOR.
speech.line: Yes, madam, fair.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Nay, never paint me now;
Where fair is not, praise cannot mend the brow.
Here (good my glass), take this for telling true:
Fair payment for foul words is more than due.

speech.speaker: FOR.
speech.line: Nothing but fair is that which you inherit.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: See, see, my beauty will be sav’d by merit.
O heresy in fair, fit for these days!
A giving hand, though foul, shall have fair praise.
But come, the bow: now mercy goes to kill,
And shooting well is then accounted ill.
Thus will I save my credit in the shoot:
Not wounding, pity would not let me do’t;
If wounding, then it was to show my skill,
That more for praise than purpose meant to kill.
And out of question so it is sometimes:
Glory grows guilty of detested crimes,
When for fame’s sake, for praise, an outward part,
We bend to that the working of the heart;
As I for praise alone now seek to spill
The poor deer’s blood, that my heart means no ill.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: Do not curst wives hold that self-sovereignty
Only for praise’ sake, when they strive to be
Lords o’er their lords?

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Only for praise—and praise we may afford
To any lady that subdues a lord.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: Here comes a member of the commonwealth.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: God dig-you-den all! Pray you, which is the head lady?

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Thou shalt know her, fellow, by the rest that have no heads.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: Which is the greatest lady, the highest?

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: The thickest and the tallest.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: The thickest and the tallest! It is so, truth is truth.
And your waist, mistress, were as slender as my wit,
One a’ these maids’ girdles for your waist should be fit.
Are not you the chief woman? You are the thickest here.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: What’s your will, sir? What’s your will?

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: I have a letter from Monsieur Berowne to one Lady Rosaline.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: O, thy letter, thy letter! He’s a good friend of mine.
Stand aside, good bearer. Boyet, you can carve,
Break up this capon.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: I am bound to serve.
This letter is mistook; it importeth none here.
It is writ to Jaquenetta.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: We will read it, I swear.
Break the neck of the wax, and every one give ear.

line.recite: “By heaven, that thou art fair, is most infallible; true, that thou art beauteous; truth itself, that thou art lovely. More fairer than fair, beautiful than beauteous, truer than truth itself, have commiseration on thy heroical vassal! The magnanimous and most illustrate King Cophetua set eye upon the pernicious and indubitate beggar Zenelophon; and he it was that might rightly say, Veni, vidi, vici; which to annothanize in the vulgar—O base and obscure vulgar!—videlicet, He came, saw, and overcame: he came, one; saw, two; overcame, three. Who came? The king. Why did he come? To see. Why did he see? To overcome. To whom came he? To the beggar. What saw he? The beggar. Who overcame he? The beggar. The conclusion is victory; on whose side? The king’s. The captive is enrich’d; on whose side? The beggar’s. The catastrophe is a nuptial; on whose side? The king’s; no, on both in one, or one in both. I am the king, for so stands the comparison; thou the beggar, for so witnesseth thy lowliness. Shall I command thy love? I may. Shall I enforce thy love? I could. Shall I entreat thy love? I will. What shalt thou exchange for rags? Robes; for tittles? Titles; for thyself? Me. Thus expecting thy reply, I profane my lips on thy foot, my eyes on thy picture, and my heart on thy every part. Thine, in the dearest design of industry,
Don Adriano de Armado.

speech.line: Thus dost thou hear the Nemean lion roar
’Gainst thee, thou lamb, that standest as his prey;
Submissive fall his princely feet before,
And he from forage will incline to play.
But if thou strive, poor soul, what art thou then?
Food for his rage, repasture for his den.”

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: What plume of feathers is he that indited this letter?
What vane? What weathercock? Did you ever hear better?

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: I am much deceived but I remember the style.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Else your memory is bad, going o’er it ere-while.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: This Armado is a Spaniard that keeps here in court,
A phantasime, a Monarcho, and one that makes sport
To the Prince and his book-mates.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Thou fellow, a word.
Who gave thee this letter?

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: I told you: my lord.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: To whom shouldst thou give it?

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: From my lord to my lady.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: From which lord to which lady?

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: From my Lord Berowne, a good master of mine,
To a lady of France that he call’d Rosaline.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Thou hast mistaken his letter. Come, lords, away.
Here, sweet, put up this—’twill be thine another day.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: Who is the shooter? Who is the shooter?

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Shall I teach you to know?

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: Ay, my continent of beauty.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Why, she that bears the bow.
Finely put off!

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: My lady goes to kill horns, but if thou marry,
Hang me by the neck if horns that year miscarry.
Finely put on!

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Well then I am the shooter.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: And who is your deer?

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: If we choose by the horns, yourself come not near.
Finely put on indeed!

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: You still wrangle with her, Boyet, and she strikes at the brow.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: But she herself is hit lower. Have I hit her now?

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Shall I come upon thee with an old saying, that was a man when King Pippen of France was a little boy, as touching the hit it?

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: So I may answer thee with one as old, that was a woman when Queen Guinover of Britain was a little wench, as touching the hit it.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Thou canst not hit it, hit it, hit it,
Thou canst not hit it, my good man.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: And I cannot, cannot, cannot,
And I cannot, another can.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: By my troth, most pleasant. How both did fit it!

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: A mark marvellous well shot, for they both did hit it.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: A mark! O, mark but that mark! A mark, says my lady!
Let the mark have a prick in’t, to mete at, if it may be.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Wide a’ the bow-hand! I’ faith, your hand is out.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: Indeed ’a must shoot nearer, or he’ll ne’er hit the clout.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: And if my hand be out, then belike your hand is in.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: Then will she get the upshoot by cleaving the pin.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Come, come, you talk greasily, your lips grow foul.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: She’s too hard for you at pricks, sir, challenge her to bowl.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: I fear too much rubbing. Good night, my good owl.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: By my soul, a swain, a most simple clown!
Lord, Lord, how the ladies and I have put him down!
O’ my troth, most sweet jests, most incony vulgar wit!
When it comes so smoothly off, so obscenely as it were, so fit.
Armado a’ th’ one side—O, a most dainty man!
To see him walk before a lady and to bear her fan!
To see him kiss his hand! And how most sweetly ’a will swear!
And his page a’ t’ other side, that handful of wit!
Ah, heavens, it is a most pathetical nit!
Sola, sola!

scene.stagedir: Enter Dull, Holofernes the Pedant, and Nathaniel from watching the hunt.

speech.speaker: NATH.
speech.line: Very reverent sport truly, and done in the testimony of a good conscience.

speech.speaker: HOL.
speech.line: The deer was (as you know) sanguis, in blood, ripe as the pomewater, who now hangeth like a jewel in the ear of caelo, the sky, the welkin, the heaven, and anon falleth like a crab on the face of terra, the soil, the land, the earth.

speech.speaker: NATH.
speech.line: Truly, Master Holofernes, the epithites are sweetly varied, like a scholar at the least; but, sir, I assure ye it was a buck of the first head.

speech.speaker: HOL.
speech.line: Sir Nathaniel, haud credo.

speech.speaker: DULL.
speech.line: ’Twas not a haud credo, ’twas a pricket.

speech.speaker: HOL.
speech.line: Most barbarous intimation! Yet a kind of insinuation, as it were in via, in way, of explication; facere, as it were, replication, or rather ostentare, to show, as it were, his inclination, after his undressed, unpolished, uneducated, unpruned, untrained, or rather unlettered, or ratherest unconfirmed fashion, to insert again my haud credo for a deer.

speech.speaker: DULL.
speech.line: I said the deer was not a haud credo, ’twas a pricket.

speech.speaker: HOL.
speech.line: Twice sod simplicity, bis coctus!
O thou monster Ignorance, how deformed dost thou look!

speech.speaker: NATH.
speech.line: Sir, he hath never fed of the dainties that are bred in a book;
He hath not eat paper, as it were; he hath not drunk ink; his intellect is not replenished; he is only an animal, only sensible in the duller parts;
And such barren plants are set before us, that we thankful should be—
Which we of taste and feeling are—for those parts that do fructify in us more than he.
For as it would ill become me to be vain, indiscreet, or a fool,
So were there a patch set on learning, to see him in a school:
But omne bene, say I, being of an old father’s mind:
Many can brook the weather that love not the wind.

speech.speaker: DULL.
speech.line: You two are book-men: can you tell me by your wit
What was a month old at Cain’s birth, that’s not five weeks old as yet?

speech.speaker: HOL.
speech.line: Dictynna, goodman Dull, Dictynna, goodman Dull.

speech.speaker: DULL.
speech.line: What is Dictynna?

speech.speaker: NATH.
speech.line: A title to Phoebe, to Luna, to the moon.

speech.speaker: HOL.
speech.line: The moon was a month old when Adam was no more,
And raught not to five weeks when he came to five-score.
Th’ allusion holds in the exchange.

speech.speaker: DULL.
speech.line: ’Tis true indeed, the collusion holds in the exchange.

speech.speaker: HOL.
speech.line: God comfort thy capacity! I say, th’ allusion holds in the exchange.

speech.speaker: DULL.
speech.line: And I say, the pollution holds in the exchange, for the moon is never but a month old; and I say beside that, ’twas a pricket that the Princess kill’d.

speech.speaker: HOL.
speech.line: Sir Nathaniel, will you hear an extemporal epitaph on the death of the deer? And to humor the ignorant, call I the deer the Princess kill’d a pricket.

speech.speaker: NATH.
speech.line: Perge, good Master Holofernes, perge, so it shall please you to abrogate squirility.

speech.speaker: HOL.
speech.line: I will something affect the letter, for it argues facility.
The preyful Princess pierc’d and prick’d a pretty pleasing pricket;
Some say a sore, but not a sore, till now made sore with shooting.
The dogs did yell: put l to sore, then sorel jumps from thicket,
Or pricket sore, or else sorel; the people fall a-hooting.
If sore be sore, then L to sore makes fifty sores o’ sorel:
Of one sore I an hundred make by adding but one more L.

speech.speaker: NATH.
speech.line: A rare talent!

speech.speaker: DULL.
speech.line: If a talent be a claw, look how he claws him with a talent.

speech.speaker: HOL.
speech.line: This is a gift that I have, simple; simple, a foolish extravagant spirit, full of forms, figures, shapes, objects, ideas, apprehensions, motions, revolutions. These are begot in the ventricle of memory, nourish’d in the womb of pia mater, and delivered upon the mellowing of occasion. But the gift is good in those in whom it is acute, and I am thankful for it.

speech.speaker: NATH.
speech.line: Sir, I praise the Lord for you, and so may my parishioners, for their sons are well tutor’d by you, and their daughters profit very greatly under you. You are a good member of the commonwealth.

speech.speaker: HOL.
speech.line: Mehercle, if their sons be ingenious, they shall want no instruction; if their daughters be capable, I will put it to them: but vir sapit qui pauca loquitur. A soul feminine saluteth us.

scene.stagedir: Enter Jaquenetta and the Clown Costard.

speech.speaker: JAQ.
speech.line: God give you good morrow, Master Person.

speech.speaker: HOL.
speech.line: Master Person, quasi pers-one. And if one should be pierc’d, which is the one?

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: Marry, Master Schoolmaster, he that is likel’est to a hogshead.

speech.speaker: HOL.
speech.line: Of piercing a hogshead! A good lustre of conceit in a turf of earth; fire enough for a flint, pearl enough for a swine: ’tis pretty; it is well.

speech.speaker: JAQ.
speech.line: Good Master Person, be so good as read me this letter. It was given me by Costard, and sent me from Don Armado. I beseech you read it.

speech.speaker: HOL.
speech.line: Facile, precor gelida quando pecus omne sub umbra ruminat, and so forth. Ah, good old Mantuan! I may speak of thee as the traveller doth of Venice:

line.italian: Che non te vede, che non te prechia.

speech.line: Old Mantuan, old Mantuan! Who understandeth thee not, loves thee not. Ut, re, sol, la, mi, fa. Under pardon, sir, what are the contents? Or rather, as Horace says in his—What, my soul, verses?

speech.speaker: NATH.
speech.line: Ay, sir, and very learned.

speech.speaker: HOL.
speech.line: Let me hear a staff, a stanze, a verse; lege, domine.

line.recite: “If love make me forsworn, how shall I swear to love?
Ah, never faith could hold, if not to beauty vowed!
Though to myself forsworn, to thee I’ll faithful prove;
Those thoughts to me were oaks, to thee like osiers bowed.
Study his bias leaves, and makes his book thine eyes,
Where all those pleasures live that art would comprehend.
If knowledge be the mark, to know thee shall suffice;
Well learned is that tongue that well can thee commend,
All ignorant that soul that sees thee without wonder;
Which is to me some praise that I thy parts admire.
Thy eye Jove’s lightning bears, thy voice his dreadful thunder,
Which, not to anger bent, is music and sweet fire.
Celestial as thou art, O, pardon love this wrong,
That sings heaven’s praise with such an earthly tongue.”

speech.speaker: HOL.
speech.line: You find not the apostraphus, and so miss the accent. Let me supervise the canzonet.

Here are only numbers ratified, but for the elegancy, facility, and golden cadence of poesy, caret. Ovidius Naso was the man. And why indeed “Naso,” but for smelling out the odoriferous flowers of fancy, the jerks of invention? Imitari is nothing: so doth the hound his master, the ape his keeper, the tired horse his rider. But, damosella virgin, was this directed to you?

speech.speaker: JAQ.
speech.line: Ay, sir, from one Monsieur Berowne, one of the strange queen’s lords.

speech.speaker: HOL.
speech.line: I will overglance the superscript: “To the snow-white hand of the most beauteous Lady Rosaline.” I will look again on the intellect of the letter, for the nomination of the party

to the person written unto: “Your ladyship’s in all desired employment, Berowne.” Sir Nathaniel, this Berowne is one of the votaries with the King, and here he hath framed a letter to a sequent of the stranger queen’s, which accidentally, or by the way of progression, hath miscarried. Trip and go, my sweet, deliver this paper into the royal hand of the King; it may concern much. Stay not thy compliment; I forgive thy duty. Adieu.

speech.speaker: JAQ.
speech.line: Good Costard, go with me. Sir, God save your life!

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: Have with thee, my girl.

speech.speaker: NATH.
speech.line: Sir, you have done this in the fear of God, very religiously; and as a certain father saith—

speech.speaker: HOL.
speech.line: Sir, tell not me of the father, I do fear colorable colors. But to return to the verses: did they please you, Sir Nathaniel?

speech.speaker: NATH.
speech.line: Marvellous well for the pen.

speech.speaker: HOL.
speech.line: I do dine today at the father’s of a certain pupil of mine, where, if (before repast) it shall please you to gratify the table with a grace, I will, on my privilege I have with the parents of the foresaid child or pupil, undertake your bien venuto; where I will prove those verses to be very unlearned, neither savoring of poetry, wit, nor invention. I beseech your society.

speech.speaker: NATH.
speech.line: And thank you too; for society, saith the text, is the happiness of life.

speech.speaker: HOL.
speech.line: And certes the text most infallibly concludes it.
Sir, I do invite you too, you shall not say me nay: pauca verba. Away, the gentles are at their game, and we will to our recreation.

scene.stagedir: Enter Berowne with a paper in his hand, alone.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: The King he is hunting the deer: I am coursing myself. They have pitch’d a toil: I am toiling in a pitch—pitch that defiles—defile! A foul word. Well, “set thee down, sorrow!” for so they say the fool said, and so say I, and I the fool: well prov’d, wit! By the Lord, this love is as mad as Ajax. It kills sheep; it kills me, I a sheep: well prov’d again a’ my side! I will not love; if I do, hang me; i’ faith, I will not. O but her eye—by this light, but for her eye, I would not love her; yes, for her two eyes. Well, I do nothing in the world but lie, and lie in my throat. By heaven, I do love, and it hath taught me to rhyme and to be mallicholy; and here is part of my rhyme, and here my mallicholy. Well, she hath one a’ my sonnets already: the clown bore it, the fool sent it, and the lady hath it: sweet clown, sweeter fool, sweetest lady! By the world, I would not care a pin, if the other three were in. Here comes one with a paper, God give him grace to groan!

scene.stagedir: He stands aside, climbing into a tree.
The King ent’reth with a paper.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Ay me!

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Shot, by heaven! Proceed, sweet Cupid, thou hast thump’d him with thy bird-bolt under the left pap. In faith, secrets!

speech.speaker: KING.

line.recite: “So sweet a kiss the golden sun gives not
To those fresh morning drops upon the rose,
As thy eye-beams, when their fresh rays have smote
The night of dew that on my cheeks down flows;
Nor shines the silver moon one half so bright
Through the transparent bosom of the deep,
As doth thy face through tears of mine give light.
Thou shin’st in every tear that I do weep,
No drop but as a coach doth carry thee;
So ridest thou triumphing in my woe.
Do but behold the tears that swell in me,
And they thy glory through my grief will show.
But do not love thyself, then thou wilt keep
My tears for glasses, and still make me weep.
O queen of queens, how far dost thou excel
No thought can think, nor tongue of mortal tell.”

speech.line: How shall she know my griefs? I’ll drop the paper.
Sweet leaves, shade folly. Who is he comes here?
speech.stagedir: Enter Longaville with a paper. The King steps aside.
speech.line: What, Longaville, and reading! Listen, ear.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Now in thy likeness, one more fool appear!

speech.speaker: LONG.
speech.line: Ay me, I am forsworn!

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Why, he comes in like a perjure, wearing papers.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: In love, I hope—sweet fellowship in shame.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: One drunkard loves another of the name.

speech.speaker: LONG.
speech.line: Am I the first that have been perjur’d so?

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: I could put thee in comfort: not by two that I know.
Thou makest the triumphery, the corner-cap of society,
The shape of love’s Tyburn that hangs up simplicity.

speech.speaker: LONG.
speech.line: I fear these stubborn lines lack power to move.
O sweet Maria, empress of my love,
These numbers will I tear, and write in prose!

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: O, rhymes are guards on wanton Cupid’s hose:
Disfigure not his shop.

speech.speaker: LONG.
speech.line: This same shall go.

line.recite: “Did not the heavenly rhetoric of thine eye,
’Gainst whom the world cannot hold argument,
Persuade my heart to this false perjury?
Vows for thee broke deserve not punishment.
A woman I forswore, but I will prove,
Thou being a goddess, I forswore not thee.
My vow was earthly, thou a heavenly love;
Thy grace being gain’d cures all disgrace in me.
Vows are but breath, and breath a vapor is;
Then thou, fair sun, which on my earth dost shine,
Exhal’st this vapor-vow; in thee it is.
If broken then, it is no fault of mine:
If by me broke, what fool is not so wise
To lose an oath to win a paradise?”

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: This is the liver-vein, which makes flesh a deity,
A green goose a goddess; pure, pure idolatry.
God amend us, God amend! We are much out a’ th’ way.

speech.speaker: LONG.
speech.line: By whom shall I send this?—Company? Stay.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: “All hid, all hid,” an old infant play.
Like a demigod here sit I in the sky,
And wretched fools’ secrets heedfully o’er-eye.
More sacks to the mill! O heavens, I have my wish!
Dumaine transformed! Four woodcocks in a dish!

speech.speaker: DUM.
speech.line: O most divine Kate!

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: O most profane coxcomb!

speech.speaker: DUM.
speech.line: By heaven, the wonder in a mortal eye!

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: By earth, she is not, corporal, there you lie.

speech.speaker: DUM.
speech.line: Her amber hairs for foul hath amber coted.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: An amber-color’d raven was well noted.

speech.speaker: DUM.
speech.line: As upright as the cedar.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Stoop, I say,
Her shoulder is with child.

speech.speaker: DUM.
speech.line: As fair as day.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Ay, as some days, but then no sun must shine.

speech.speaker: DUM.
speech.line: O that I had my wish!

speech.speaker: LONG.
speech.line: And I had mine!

speech.speaker: KING
speech.line: And mine too, good Lord!

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Amen, so I had mine. Is not that a good word?

speech.speaker: DUM.
speech.line: I would forget her, but a fever she
Reigns in my blood, and will rememb’red be.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: A fever in your blood! Why then incision
Would let her out in saucers. Sweet misprision!

speech.speaker: DUM.
speech.line: Once more I’ll read the ode that I have writ.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Once more I’ll mark how love can vary wit.

speech.speaker: DUM.

line.recite: “On a day—alack the day!—
Love, whose month is ever May,
Spied a blossom passing fair
Playing in the wanton air:
Through the velvet leaves the wind,
All unseen, can passage find;
That the lover, sick to death,
Wish’d himself the heavens’ breath.
Air, quoth he, thy cheeks may blow;
Air, would I might triumph so!
But, alack, my hand is sworn
ne’er to pluck thee from thy thorn;
Vow, alack, for youth unmeet,
Youth so apt to pluck a sweet.
Do not call it sin in me,
That I am forsworn for thee;
Thou for whom Jove would swear
Juno but an Ethiop were,
And deny himself for Jove,
Turning mortal for thy love.”

speech.line: This will I send and something else more plain
That shall express my true love’s fasting pain.
O would the King, Berowne, and Longaville
Were lovers too! Ill, to example ill,
Would from my forehead wipe a perjur’d note:
For none offend where all alike do dote.

speech.speaker: LONG.
speech.line: Dumaine, thy love is far from charity,
That in love’s grief desir’st society:
You may look pale, but I should blush, I know,
To be o’erheard and taken napping so.

speech.speaker: KING
speech.line: Come, sir, you blush; as his your case is such;
You chide at him, offending twice as much.
You do not love Maria? Longaville
Did never sonnet for her sake compile,
Nor never lay his wreathed arms athwart
His loving bosom to keep down his heart.
I have been closely shrouded in this bush
And mark’d you both, and for you both did blush.
I heard your guilty rhymes, observ’d your fashion,
Saw sighs reek from you, noted well your passion.
“Ay me!” says one, “O Jove!” the other cries;
One, her hairs were gold, crystal the other’s eyes.
You would for paradise break faith and troth,
And Jove for your love would infringe an oath.
What will Berowne say when that he shall hear
Faith infringed, which such zeal did swear?
How will he scorn! How will he spend his wit!
How will he triumph, leap, and laugh at it!
For all the wealth that ever I did see,
I would not have him know so much by me.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Now step I forth to whip hypocrisy.
Ah, good my liege, I pray thee pardon me!
Good heart, what grace hast thou thus to reprove
These worms for loving, that art most in love?
Your eyes do make no coaches; in your tears
There is no certain princess that appears;
You’ll not be perjur’d, ’tis a hateful thing;
Tush, none but minstrels like of sonneting!
But are you not asham’d? Nay, are you not,
All three of you, to be thus much o’ershot?
You found his mote, the King your mote did see;
But I a beam do find in each of three.
O, what a scene of fool’ry have I seen,
Of sighs, of groans, of sorrow, and of teen!
O me, with what strict patience have I sat,
To see a king transformed to a gnat!
To see great Hercules whipping a gig,
And profound Salomon to tune a jig,
And Nestor play at push-pin with the boys,
And critic Timon laugh at idle toys!
Where lies thy grief, O, tell me, good Dumaine?
And, gentle Longaville, where lies thy pain?
And where my liege’s? All about the breast!
A caudle ho!

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Too bitter is thy jest.
Are we betrayed thus to thy over-view?

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Not you by me, but I betrayed to you:
I that am honest, I that hold it sin
To break the vow I am engaged in.
I am betrayed by keeping company
With men like you, men of inconstancy.
When shall you see me write a thing in rhyme,
Or groan for Joan, or spend a minute’s time
In pruning me? When shall you hear that I
Will praise a hand, a foot, a face, an eye,
A gait, a state, a brow, a breast, a waist,
A leg, a limb—

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Soft, whither away so fast?
A true man, or a thief, that gallops so?

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: I post from love; good lover, let me go.

speech.speaker: JAQ.
speech.line: God bless the King!

speech.speaker: KING.
